PUNK BAGGED IN
ROBBERY OF YMCA
A dramatization of Saturday's brutal, wanton, rape of a Levering Pepsi Machine.

Two hours after last Saturday night's mixer, a young
burglar was nabbed in the act of seeking the Levering Hall
vending maehines.
-Earlier Sunday morning, two night watclimon were making their rounds when they spottod a disturbance in the lobby
of the 'YMCA. When they entered a .rou fig man, not identified,
was prying his way iuto the eoin box of the cigarette vending
mach ine.
The two watchmen, Mr. Hackmeyer and Mr. Harry Herons
cornered and seized the intruder. Leading him into the administrative offices of the YMCA, they called for further
assistance. Dr. - Wickwire reported that the YMCA offices appeared to have been the scene of a struggle.
Mr. William Campbetl. a security officer of the University
said that the burglar was not a student of the University,
but that similar pranks, committed by Hopkins Students were
not entirely unknown. He also noted that this was the second
such arrest in the last month.
The security officer did not wish to spevulate MI how the
entrance was made into Levering Hall, though he admitted
that the burglar might have hidden in the building for two
hours after the mixer.
The accused is being hold for grand jury action.

After Dr. Eisenhower presented the University Report on

• That a committee of students be set up to test the adherence of landlords renting to

• That a Negro be selected to
work on the staff of the admissions committee.
• That greater exchange programs be carried through with
Hopkins and Howard.
• That a summer program be
set up at Hopkins for preparing
minority
"underprivileged
groups" for college work.
These were among many less
articulate suggestions.

NEWS-LETTER

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE DECEMBER 17, 1965

CAMPUS NOTES
Son of op Art
During the month of December, The Baltimore Museum of
Art will present two strikingly
different exhibitions, one an assemblage of modern perceptual
abstractions, or "op art", and
the other a display of 15 paintings by the 17th Century Dutch
painter Hendrick Terbrugghen.
Both shows are of major importance in the Museum's winter
schedule and both are loan exhibitions. The "op art" show,
called "The Responsive Eye",
opens December 14 (and runs
through January 23). "Terbrugthen in America" opens on December 19 4t0 January 30).
"Terbrugghen in America" is
So titled because the exhibition
Is made up of the 15 large canvases in America by the artist.
The Baltimore Museum and the
Dayton Art Institute, Ohio, are
go-sponsors and jointly organbed this show through the el/orbs of the directors of the two

museums, Mr. Thomas C. Colt,
Jr., of Dayton and Mr. Charles
Parkhurst of the Baltimore Museum. In the past 10 years, there
has been a resurgence of interest
in the masterpieces of Terbrugghen both in Europe and America, and enthusiasm for use of
color, composition, and place in
the history of art.
The exhibition marks the first
time any Terbrugghen painting
has been shown in Baltimore and
the first time all of the Terbrugghen paintings in the Americas
have been gathered together for
public viewing.

Hop Review
Sunday, December 19 at 3 p.m.,
on the Johns Hopkins Review
Dr. Paul M. A. Linebarger, Far
East expert and occasional advisor to China's Nationalist government, will report his findings
from two trips taken this year
in the Far East and southeast
Asia.

Dr. Linebarger received a
Doctor of Civil Law degree from
the National Chengchi University on Taiwan last month and,
at that time, conferred with
Chiang Kai-Shek.

Gould Quits SC
Proposes Change
9

Barry Gould, chairman of the
Membership Re-evaluation Committee of the Student Council
submitted a lengthy report Monday night presenting a four-point
proposal which he feels the organization must adopt if it is
not to fall into stagnation leading to its ultimate demise. At
the end of the meeting, Gould
tendered
his resignation
to
Council President Shelley Earp.
"The Student Council," Gould
reported. 'is no longer a representative body because It no
longer represents the student
body." Furthermore, Gould said
that the respect accorded the
Council was based solely on respect for the individuals - within
the organization, and not on the
organization itself.
The four recommendations for
revitalization of the Council are:
1. The Council must integrate
the class presidents by giving
them a vote.
2. The Council must reject its
past role of mere reaction to administrative decisions and instead voice its opinion on significant issues.
3. The Council should attempt
to secure administrative cooperation in developing its new role
as a meaningful and respected
organiaztion.

4. The Council must initiate
an intensive "public relations"
program to gain respect from the
undergraduate body. This might
be accomplished, Gould explained, by encouraging non-Council
members to participate in Council activities, eliciting opinions
from students on major issues,
and cooperating with the NewsLetter in publicizing its activities.
In the ensuing discussion,
John Brickman expressed his
feeling that the present "fractionalization" is preferable to
"monolitic unity." Jim Mongiardo, junior class president reflected the opinion of the class
presidents that it seemed strange
under the present system, that
class leaders were not a part of
the student government.
Gould resigned his seat on the
Council in the face of the
Council's alleged immobility and
unresponsiveness. He was the
Honor Commission representative.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, DECEMBER 17, 1965

HEWS-LETTER

PAGE

pra

,
MIngwasm•..101.•

.o

Hip Cleric Backs Beat Christ
tContinued from Page 3)
tant both in religion and life. A
celebration should be an outflow
of emotions, but, he maintained,
a church was the last place you
would want to celebrate something. An atmosphere of silence
pervades the place. At his
church, they experiment with
Sunday morning services. All the
pews are removed and tables are
set up with food. People eat, sing,
and discuss and announcements
of what's going on in the Village
are made. After a while, a brief
communion service is held which
People are free to participate in
as they please. Reverend Moody
added that he felt non-verbal
communication was very important.
Moody Challenged
Reverend Moody was challenged several times on the question of communication. He was
asked to define his terms, such
as celebration and was challenged on the value of a new
jargon which would just replace
the old. Greenwich Village jargon, it was said, would be just as
restrictive as the present terminology. Reverend Moody maintained that you don't have to
tell people what they are celebrating. They just celebrate from
their own emotions of life, be it
a joyous or tragic celebration.
The new jargon, he asserted, is
the jargon of the 20th century
and concerns itself with the
Problems of the modern world.
The Church is going to have to
Shed its self-conscious theological sermonizing, he declared, and
is going to be forced to talk about
reality. No matter how important
"redemption" is to us, he added,
means
Green
'redemption
Stamps to most people." He also
aaid that there was nothing
strange or restrictive about the
language of the Village since its
People come from all over the
Country and he was not referring
to any beat type language.
Catholic Opinion
A Roman Catholic stated that
the service was, for him, a
communication with God and he
could not accept the Reverend's
definition of it as a ritualized
Cult, The Reverend answered
that this was hard for both
Catholics and Protestants to accept, although harder for Catholics. He pointed to the example

of the prophets who chastized
the people for making animal
sacrifices and ignoring the sufferings of the people. He said
that it was not sufficient to dress
something up with ritual and
call it divine. A special language
Is not needed.
Reverend Moody also stated
that he did not want to cut the
past off from the present, but
that it was necessary to go back
to the roots of a custom and
find its original purpose to see
how it can be meaningful now.
He concluded by stating that an

important innovation was the
stripping down of the Church's
structure so that structure and
organization would not prevent
the Church from acting. In the
modern world, he said, the
Church must be dynamic and
able to react quickly in a situation.
After the lecture, interested
people were invited to buy their
dinner in the Levering Hall cafeteria and then attend a discussion and dinner in the Sherwood
Room.

THE BLUEBIRD OF HAPPINESS
HAS FLOWN THE COOP
Can education bring happiness?
This is a question that in recent years has caused much
lively debate and several hundred stabbings among American college professors. Some contend that if a student's intellect is sufficiently aroused, happiness will automatically
follow. Others say that to concentrate on the intellect and
ignore the rest of the personality can only lead to misery.
I myself favor the second view, and I offer in evidence
the well-known case of Knut Fusco.
Knut, a forestry major, never got anything less than a
straight "A," was awarded his B.T. (Bachelor of Trees) in
only two years, his M.S.B. (Master of Sap and Bark) in
only three,and his D.B.C.(Doctor of Blight and Cutworms)
in only four.
Academic glory was his. His intellect was the envy of
every intellect fan on campus. But was he happy? The answer, alas, was no. Knut—he knew not why—was miserable; so miserable, in fact, that one day while walking
across campus, he was suddenly so overcome with melancholy that he flung himself, weeping, upon the statue of the
Founder.
By and by,a liberal arts coed named Nikki Sigafoos came
by with her Barby doll. She noted Knut's condition. "How
come you're so unhappy, hey?" said Nikki.
"Suppose you tell me, you dumb old liberal arts major,"
replied Knut peevishly.
"All right, I will," said Nikki."You are unhappy for two
reasons. First, because you have been so busy stuffing your
intellect that you have gone and starved your psyche.
I've got nothing
against learning,
mind you, but a person oughtn't to neglect the pleasant,
gentle amenities of
life—the fun things.
Have you, for instance, ever been to
a dance?"
Knut shook his
head.
"Have you ever "
...and then to a justice of the peace.*
watched a sunset?
Written a poem? Shaved with a Personna Stainless Steel
Blade?"
Knut shook his head.
"Well, we'll fix that right, now,"said Nikki,and gave him
a razor, a Personna Stainless Steel Blade, and a can of
Burma Shave.
Knut lathered with the Burma Shave and shaved with
the Personna and for the first time in many long years he
smiled. He smiled and then he laughed—peal after peal of
reverberating joy. "Wow-dow!" he cried. "What a shave!
Does Personna come in injector style, too?"
"It does," said Nikki.
"Gloriosky!" cried Knut."And does Burma Shave come
In menthol, too?"
"It does," said Nikki.
"Huzzah!"cried Knut."Now that I have found Personna
and Burma Shave I will never have another unhappy day."
"Hold!" said Nikki. "Personna and Burma Shave alone
will not solve your problem—only half of it. Remember I
said there were two things making you unhappy?"
"Oh, yeah,"said Knut."What's the other one?"
"How long have you had that bear trap on your foot?"
said Nikki.
"I stepped on it during a field trip in my freshman year,",
said Knut."I keep meaning to have it taken off."
"Allow me,"said Nikki and removed it.
"Land's sakes, what a relief!" said Knut, now totally
happy, and took Nikki's hand and led her to a Personna
vendor and then to a justice of the peace.
Today Knut is a perfectly fulfilled man, both intellect.
wise and personalitywise. He lives in a charming split-level
house with Nikki and their 17 children and he rises steadily
in the forestry game. Only last month, in fact, he becalm*
Consultant on Sawdust to the American Butchers Guild,
he was named an Honorary Sequoia by the park commis-,
sioner of Las Vegas, and he published a beet-selling boob;
called .1 Was a Slippery Elm for the FBI.
0 1465. Max%whim.
* * *
The makers of Personna* Stainless Steel Blades and
Burma Shaw are pleased that Knut is finally out
of the woods—and so will you be if your goal is luxury shaving. Just try Personna and Burma Shave.

Frosh Hoopsters Down Garnets
After a loss in its opener the
freshman basketball team rebounded with a 74-54 victory
over the Swarthmore jayvee
Saturday.
Coach Barrette's team, playing
the season opener on its own
court, dropped a 57-58 decision
to Mt. St. Joe. The Jays led by
four points with a minute and
a half left in the game. They
were unable to hold the margin,
however, and Mt. St. Joe pulled
out the victory.

A basketball team which lacks
height and does not have a super
scorer who can bear the brunt
of the attack must compensate
by tremencious hustle, a consistent fa.st break, an a.ggres.sive

We set out to ruin
some ball bearings and
failed successfully

out to ruin some ball bearings
by smearing them with an
icky guck called molybdenum
disulfide (MoS2)Swock! This solid lubricant, used a certain
way, actually increased the life expectancy
of the ball bearings by a factor
of ten! Now the motors can run
for at least a decade without
lubrication.
We've learned from our
"failures." Our aim: investigate
everything.
The only experiment that can
really be said to "fail" is the
one that is never tried.

PUNK BAGGED IN
ROBBERY OF YMCA
A dramatization of Saturday's brutal, wanton, rape of a Levering Pepsi Machine.

Two hours after last Saturday night's mixer, a young
burglar was nabbed in the act of seeking the Levering Hall
vending maehines.
-Earlier Sunday morning, two night watclimon were making their rounds when they spottod a disturbance in the lobby
of the 'YMCA. When they entered a .rou fig man, not identified,
was prying his way iuto the eoin box of the cigarette vending
mach ine.
The two watchmen, Mr. Hackmeyer and Mr. Harry Herons
cornered and seized the intruder. Leading him into the administrative offices of the YMCA, they called for further
assistance. Dr. - Wickwire reported that the YMCA offices appeared to have been the scene of a struggle.
Mr. William Campbetl. a security officer of the University
said that the burglar was not a student of the University,
but that similar pranks, committed by Hopkins Students were
not entirely unknown. He also noted that this was the second
such arrest in the last month.
The security officer did not wish to spevulate MI how the
entrance was made into Levering Hall, though he admitted
that the burglar might have hidden in the building for two
hours after the mixer.
The accused is being hold for grand jury action.

NEWS-LETTER

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE DECEMBER 17, 1965

CAMPUS NOTES
Son of op Art
During the month of December, The Baltimore Museum of
Art will present two strikingly
different exhibitions, one an assemblage of modern perceptual
abstractions, or "op art", and
the other a display of 15 paintings by the 17th Century Dutch
painter Hendrick Terbrugghen.
Both shows are of major importance in the Museum's winter
schedule and both are loan exhibitions. The "op art" show,
called "The Responsive Eye",
opens December 14 (and runs
through January 23). "Terbrugthen in America" opens on December 19 4t0 January 30).
"Terbrugghen in America" is
So titled because the exhibition
Is made up of the 15 large canvases in America by the artist.
The Baltimore Museum and the
Dayton Art Institute, Ohio, are
go-sponsors and jointly organbed this show through the el/orbs of the directors of the two

museums, Mr. Thomas C. Colt,
Jr., of Dayton and Mr. Charles
Parkhurst of the Baltimore Museum. In the past 10 years, there
has been a resurgence of interest
in the masterpieces of Terbrugghen both in Europe and America, and enthusiasm for use of
color, composition, and place in
the history of art.
The exhibition marks the first
time any Terbrugghen painting
has been shown in Baltimore and
the first time all of the Terbrugghen paintings in the Americas
have been gathered together for
public viewing.

at that time, conferred with

Gould Quits SC
Proposes Change
9

Barry Gould, chairman of the
Membership Re-evaluation Committee of the Student Council
submitted a lengthy report Monday night presenting a four-point
proposal which he feels the organization must adopt if it is
not to fall into stagnation leading to its ultimate demise. At
the end of the meeting, Gould
tendered
his resignation
to
Council President Shelley Earp.
"The Student Council," Gould
reported. 'is no longer a representative body because It no
longer represents the student
body." Furthermore, Gould said
that the respect accorded the
Council was based solely on respect for the individuals - within
the organization, and not on the
organization itself.
The four recommendations for
revitalization of the Council are:
1. The Council must integrate
the class presidents by giving
them a vote.
2. The Council must reject its
past role of mere reaction to administrative decisions and instead voice its opinion on significant issues.
3. The Council should attempt
to secure administrative cooperation in developing its new role
as a meaningful and respected
organiaztion.

4. The Council must initiate
an intensive "public relations"
program to gain respect from the
undergraduate body. This might
be accomplished, Gould explained, by encouraging non-Council
members to participate in Council activities, eliciting opinions
from students on major issues,
and cooperating with the NewsLetter in publicizing its activities.
In the ensuing discussion,
John Brickman expressed his
feeling that the present "fractionalization" is preferable to
"monolitic unity." Jim Mongiardo, junior class president reflected the opinion of the class
presidents that it seemed strange
under the present system, that
class leaders were not a part of
the student government.
Gould resigned his seat on the
Council in the face of the
Council's alleged immobility and
unresponsiveness. He was the
Honor Commission representative.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, DECEMBER 17, 1965

HEWS-LETTER

PAGE

pra

,
MIngwasm•..101.•

.o

Hip Cleric Backs Beat Christ
tContinued from Page 3)
tant both in religion and life. A
celebration should be an outflow
of emotions, but, he maintained,
a church was the last place you
would want to celebrate something. An atmosphere of silence
pervades the place. At his
church, they experiment with
Sunday morning services. All the
pews are removed and tables are
set up with food. People eat, sing,
and discuss and announcements
of what's going on in the Village
are made. After a while, a brief
communion service is held which
People are free to participate in
as they please. Reverend Moody
added that he felt non-verbal
communication was very important.
Moody Challenged
Reverend Moody was challenged several times on the question of communication. He was
asked to define his terms, such
as celebration and was challenged on the value of a new
jargon which would just replace
the old. Greenwich Village jargon, it was said, would be just as
restrictive as the present terminology. Reverend Moody maintained that you don't have to
tell people what they are celebrating. They just celebrate from
their own emotions of life, be it
a joyous or tragic celebration.
The new jargon, he asserted, is
the jargon of the 20th century
and concerns itself with the
Problems of the modern world.
The Church is going to have to
Shed its self-conscious theological sermonizing, he declared, and
is going to be forced to talk about
reality. No matter how important
"redemption" is to us, he added,
means
Green
'redemption
Stamps to most people." He also
aaid that there was nothing
strange or restrictive about the
language of the Village since its
People come from all over the
Country and he was not referring
to any beat type language.
Catholic Opinion
A Roman Catholic stated that
the service was, for him, a
communication with God and he
could not accept the Reverend's
definition of it as a ritualized
Cult, The Reverend answered
that this was hard for both
Catholics and Protestants to accept, although harder for Catholics. He pointed to the example

of the prophets who chastized
the people for making animal
sacrifices and ignoring the sufferings of the people. He said
that it was not sufficient to dress
something up with ritual and
call it divine. A special language
Is not needed.
Reverend Moody also stated
that he did not want to cut the
past off from the present, but
that it was necessary to go back
to the roots of a custom and
find its original purpose to see
how it can be meaningful now.
He concluded by stating that an

important innovation was the
stripping down of the Church's
structure so that structure and
organization would not prevent
the Church from acting. In the
modern world, he said, the
Church must be dynamic and
able to react quickly in a situation.
After the lecture, interested
people were invited to buy their
dinner in the Levering Hall cafeteria and then attend a discussion and dinner in the Sherwood
Room.

THE BLUEBIRD OF HAPPINESS
HAS FLOWN THE COOP
Can education bring happiness?
This is a question that in recent years has caused much
lively debate and several hundred stabbings among American college professors. Some contend that if a student's intellect is sufficiently aroused, happiness will automatically
follow. Others say that to concentrate on the intellect and
ignore the rest of the personality can only lead to misery.
I myself favor the second view, and I offer in evidence
the well-known case of Knut Fusco.
Knut, a forestry major, never got anything less than a
straight "A," was awarded his B.T. (Bachelor of Trees) in
only two years, his M.S.B. (Master of Sap and Bark) in
only three,and his D.B.C.(Doctor of Blight and Cutworms)
in only four.
Academic glory was his. His intellect was the envy of
every intellect fan on campus. But was he happy? The answer, alas, was no. Knut—he knew not why—was miserable; so miserable, in fact, that one day while walking
across campus, he was suddenly so overcome with melancholy that he flung himself, weeping, upon the statue of the
Founder.
By and by,a liberal arts coed named Nikki Sigafoos came
by with her Barby doll. She noted Knut's condition. "How
come you're so unhappy, hey?" said Nikki.
"Suppose you tell me, you dumb old liberal arts major,"
replied Knut peevishly.
"All right, I will," said Nikki."You are unhappy for two
reasons. First, because you have been so busy stuffing your
intellect that you have gone and starved your psyche.
I've got nothing
against learning,
mind you, but a person oughtn't to neglect the pleasant,
gentle amenities of
life—the fun things.
Have you, for instance, ever been to
a dance?"
Knut shook his
head.
"Have you ever "
...and then to a justice of the peace.*
watched a sunset?
Written a poem? Shaved with a Personna Stainless Steel
Blade?"
Knut shook his head.
"Well, we'll fix that right, now,"said Nikki,and gave him
a razor, a Personna Stainless Steel Blade, and a can of
Burma Shave.
Knut lathered with the Burma Shave and shaved with
the Personna and for the first time in many long years he
smiled. He smiled and then he laughed—peal after peal of
reverberating joy. "Wow-dow!" he cried. "What a shave!
Does Personna come in injector style, too?"
"It does," said Nikki.
"Gloriosky!" cried Knut."And does Burma Shave come
In menthol, too?"
"It does," said Nikki.
"Huzzah!"cried Knut."Now that I have found Personna
and Burma Shave I will never have another unhappy day."
"Hold!" said Nikki. "Personna and Burma Shave alone
will not solve your problem—only half of it. Remember I
said there were two things making you unhappy?"
"Oh, yeah,"said Knut."What's the other one?"
"How long have you had that bear trap on your foot?"
said Nikki.
"I stepped on it during a field trip in my freshman year,",
said Knut."I keep meaning to have it taken off."
"Allow me,"said Nikki and removed it.
"Land's sakes, what a relief!" said Knut, now totally
happy, and took Nikki's hand and led her to a Personna
vendor and then to a justice of the peace.
Today Knut is a perfectly fulfilled man, both intellect.
wise and personalitywise. He lives in a charming split-level
house with Nikki and their 17 children and he rises steadily
in the forestry game. Only last month, in fact, he becalm*
Consultant on Sawdust to the American Butchers Guild,
he was named an Honorary Sequoia by the park commis-,
sioner of Las Vegas, and he published a beet-selling boob;
called .1 Was a Slippery Elm for the FBI.
0 1465. Max%whim.
* * *
The makers of Personna* Stainless Steel Blades and
Burma Shaw are pleased that Knut is finally out
of the woods—and so will you be if your goal is luxury shaving. Just try Personna and Burma Shave.

After a loss in its opener the

however, and Mt. St. Joe pulled
out the victory.

We set out to ruin
some ball bearings and
failed successfully

out to ruin some ball bearings
by smearing them with an
icky guck called molybdenum
disulfide (MoS2)Swock! This solid lubricant, used a certain
way, actually increased the life expectancy
of the ball bearings by a factor
of ten! Now the motors can run
for at least a decade without
lubrication.
We've learned from our
"failures." Our aim: investigate
everything.
The only experiment that can
really be said to "fail" is the
one that is never tried.
